intro: Distylium racemosum f. angustifolium, commonly known as the narrow-leaved mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to parts of eastern Australia. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, lance-shaped leaves that are typically arranged alternately along its stems. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that are often clustered in racemes, and it relies on a symbiotic relationship with its host trees for nutrients. Its seeds are dispersed by birds, which consume the fleshy, red berries and excrete the seeds in new locations. This species plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by contributing to the structure and diversity of forest ecosystems.
